We also find that children born to educated women tend to have higher HAZ scores and are less likely to be stunted and severely stunted compared to those whose mothers have no formal education.

statement.text: Pseudo R2 value is same in both Pre-monsoon season and Post-monsoon season.

The results presented in Table 4 show that excessive rainfall increases the risk of stunting for children during the monsoon season or the months before, while children born later in the year are not affected.
There are 4 seasons in period of birth.

Since mothers education is a categorical variable, Table 5 shows a coefficient for each level of education with no education being the reference category.
The reduced model shows the total effect of mothers education on child stunting before the inclusion of potential mediators.

caption.text: Description and summary statistics of mediator variables.

cell.text: Respondent has heard of HIV (yes = 1; no = 0)
Household has mosquito bed net for sleeping (yes = 1; no = 0)
Proper disposal of child’s stool (yes = 1; no = 0)
Made at least 1 antenatal care visit during latest pregnancy (yes = 1; no = 0)
Gave birth in a health facility under the supervision of a trained professional (yes = 1; no = 0)
Child has received full vaccination (yes = 1; no = 0)
Respondent participates in decision making concerning health-care, large household purchases and visits to friends and relatives and does not justify wife beating in any situation (yes = 1; no = 0)
